thread.title_full: UPDATE 2-Brazil downgraded to junk rating by S&P, deepening woes | Reuters

author: Reuters
title: UPDATE 2-Brazil downgraded to junk rating by S&P, deepening woes
text:
(Adds government reaction, analyst comment)
By Walter Brandimarte
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept 9 (Reuters) - Standard & Poor's downgraded Brazil to junk-grade credit rating on Wednesday, further hampering President Dilma Rousseff's efforts to regain market trust and pull Latin America's largest economy out of recession.
The faster-than-anticipated downgrade from investment grade will likely rock Brazilian financial markets on Thursday and will increase borrowing costs for the government and Brazilian companies.
Brazil first won its investment-grade credit rating in 2008 and the S&P downgrade is a major setback for Rousseff as she tries to kick-start the economy and shore up weak public finances.
It further sours market sentiment about the country and Brazilian assets will lose valuable funding because many investors are not allowed to buy or hold onto investments that are not rated investment grade.
S&P cut Brazil's rating to BB-plus, the highest junk rating, from BBB-minus.
It warned less than two months ago that a downgrade was possible but the unusually fast move underscores how quickly Brazil's economy has deteriorated. The outlook on the new rating remains negative, which means additional downgrades are possible in the near term.
The investment-grade rating was a key imprimatur that solidified Brazil's emergence as an economic power during a decade-long commodities boom that fizzled in recent years as the Chinese economy, Brazil's biggest export market and once ravenous for its raw materials, began slowing.
Further fallout from the downgrade will depend on whether Brazil retains investment grade ratings from other major agencies.
Fitch Ratings currently rates Brazil at BBB, two notches above investment grade, with a negative outlook. Moody's Investors Service downgraded Brazil less than a month ago to the brink of junk, but said its investment grade was safe for now.
S&P said on Wednesday its decision was based on the mounting political problems that have muddled economic policy.
These problems, S&P said, have been weighing on the government's "ability and willingness" to submit a 2016 budget consistent with the significant policy fixes Rousseff promised after she won re-election last year.
Rousseff's planning minister, Nelson Barbosa, said after the downgrade that the government would continue to honor its financial commitments and move ahead with efforts to get Congress to cooperate on much-needed economic reforms.
But S&P's move caught Rousseff's economic team off guard.
"We did not expect a downgrade now," said a person at the finance ministry who requested anonymity, adding that it was too early to determine how it will affect the government's austerity efforts.
Investors speculated whether the move would serve as a wake-up call for the government and Congress to move faster on those measures, or whether it would encourage Rousseff to change tack and boost spending once more to stimulate the economy.
"Now that the battle to preserve investment grade is lost ... there is some probability that the government could waver even further," Goldman Sachs senior economist Alberto Ramos said in a note to clients.
When Brazil first got the coveted investment-grade stamp from S&P, after decades of financial volatility, it was considered a star among developing nations.
Leveraging soaring export and tax revenues at the time, the ruling Workers' Party broadened generous social welfare programs and encouraged lending by public banks, fueling a prolonged consumer boom. Combined, the measures lifted 40 million people out of poverty.
Once Rousseff took office in 2011, however, the economy began to slow down sharply and last quarter it officially entered a recession.
The economy has also been weighed down by a massive corruption scandal at state-run oil firm Petroleo Brasileiro SA , freezing many infrastructure investments.
Brazil's currency, the real, has slumped and the inflation rate has jumped to almost 10 percent. The economic crises and the corruption scandal have both battered Rousseff's approval ratings, which are now in single digits, fuelling opposition calls for her resignation or impeachment. (Reporting by Walter Brandimarte; Editing by Cynthia Osterman and Kieran Murray)
